can anyone tell how to solve these type of questions  What is the maximum number of subnets and hosts per subnet for the 192.168.50.247 255.255.255.224 network?

Homework Answers✔✔✔✔ Answer 1: Given IP Add is 201.1.1.0, class C IP Address and default subnet mask is 255.255.255.0. Given number of hosts=40 which has 6 bits. So, Subnet generator will be 64 and Octet 4. New subnet mask will be 255.255.255.192 or /26. Number of subnets will be 2^2=4 and usable hosts in each subnet will be (2^6) - 2.  Answer 2:  Given IP Add is 170.15.0.0, class B IP Address and default subnet mask is 255.255.0.0. Given number of hosts=1000 (binary 1111101000)  which has 10 bits. So, Subnet generator will be 4 and Octet 3. New subnet mask will be 255.255.252.0 or /22. Number of subnets will be 2^6=64 and usable hosts in each subnet will be (2^10) - 2.  Answer 3: Given IP Add is 15.0.0.0, class A IP Address and default subnet mask is 255.0.0.0. Given number of hosts=100(binary 1100100) which has 7 bits. So, Subnet generator will be 128 and Octet 4. New subnet mask will be 255.255.255.128 or /25. Number of subnets will be 2^17 and usable hosts in each subnet will be (2^7) - 2.

Answer to H.W. :   H.W.1 : Class C, 255.255.255.0, 40 Hosts Given so 101000 = 6 bits reserved from right to left, Subnet Generator = 64, Octet Position = 4, New Subnet Mask is 255.255.255.192 or /26, Number of Networks / Subnets = 2^2 = 4 and Usable Host IP Addresses = 2^6-2  H.W.2 : Class B, 255.255.0.0, 1000 Hosts Given so 1111101000 = 10 bits reserved from right to left, Subnet Generator = 4, Octet Position = 3, New Subnet Mask is 255.255.252.0 or /22, Number of Networks / Subnets = 2^6 and Usable Host IP Addresses = 2^10-2  H.W.3 : Class A, 255.0.0.0, 100 Hosts Given so 1100100 = 7 bits reserved from right to left, Subnet Generator = 128, Octet Position = 4, New Subnet Mask is 255.255.255.128 or /25, Number of Networks / Subnets = 2^17 and Usable Host IP Addresses = 2^7-2

Well it turns out that I'm wrong. You in fact have to count the network bits you borrow starting from the default subnet mask, given by the IP Adress Class. And all those borrowed bits represents the number of networks that are created from this new subnet mask. This another video covers that perspective https://youtu.be/vY4cjGpRiIs?si=XAQmkY-kBM62MUDU
we do not count the 1's in first octet because the 1's in first octet are already present in class B's default subnet mask, counting only the 1's that are newly added to the new subnet mask
CONSIDER ONLY CHANGEABLE OCTETS

Well we know that its a class C IP address. and so the first 3 octets of the subnet mask will be filled with ones. hence only the last octet in this case allows us some flexibility. So if you convert 224 to binary youll see 11100000. the number of hosts are dictated by the number of zeros in this octet. So 2^5 - 2 hosts are possible per subnet. The number of subnets are given by the number of ones, that is 2^3 or 8 subnets.for the number of subnets you can think of it as. Each subnet will have 32 ip addresses available. You can only play with 8 bits here. so the total number of subnets is 2^8 / 2^5 that is 2^3 or 8.   if it were class B and each subnet has 32 ip addresses. You have 16 bits that are not fixed by the class itself. so the total number of subnets will be 2^16/2^5.

2^2 = 4 how is it..

So basically it belongs to class A where 10 is already given, the remaining network part will be _.255.255._, which when converted to bits come out to be 8+8=16 and plus the bit which is in the 4th octect. So total is 17.
The answer 10.200.20.15 is actually correct.

@chakrikaanoushapinisetty2197  i think rajesh answer is right... in classless ip addressing you have to account for subnet bits and not network bits... the network bits are taken into account only in classful addressing....its like this according to my understanding...  the default subnet mask in binary is: 11111111.11111111.11111111.00000000  while the new subnet mask will be: 11111111.11111111.11111111.11000000  we can see that change has occurred only in the 4th octet, the first 3 octets remains unchanged... so the subnets and hosts per subnet will be decided on the basis of 4th octet...  for the number of subnets: since there are two 1s in the 4th octet so the number of subnets will be 2 power 2 which equals 4  and for the number of hosts per subnet, since we have six 0s in the 4th octet so 2 power 6 will equal 64 and of course -2 so 62....
